questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with gastrointestinal symptoms after consuming poorly cooked meat. A stool examination reveals the presence of eggs or gravid proglottids, suggesting a diagnosis of taeniasis. Which of the following statements regarding the causative agents of this infection is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: The eggs of Taenia saginata are infective to humans

options.label: B
options.text: The infective stage of Taenia saginata is Cysticercus bovis

options.label: C
options.text: The eggs of Taenia solium are not infective to humans.

options.label: D
options.text: Taenia solium is acquired through poorly cooked beef

questions.correct_answer: B. The infective stage of Taenia saginata is Cysticercus bovis
questions.explanation:
Taenia Species

T. saginata

T.solium

Definitive Host

Man

Man

Intermediate Host

Cattle (cow or buffalo)

Pig

Larva

Cysticercus bovis; present in cow not in man

Cysticercus cellulosae; present in pig and also in man

Egg

Not infective to man (Option A)

Infective to man (Option C)

Mode of Infection

Ingestion of the larval stage in poorly cooked cattle (cow or buffalo) meat.

Ingestion of the larval stage in poorly cooked pig meat. (Option D)

Diagnostic Form

Eggs or gravid proglottids in feces

Infective Form

Cysticercus bovis (Option B)

Cysticercus cellulosae

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with abdominal pain and diarrhea. A stool sample is analyzed, revealing the presence of eggs that are oval in shape, have a smooth outer surface, and lack an operculum similar to the image given below. Given these findings, which of the following treatments is the most appropriate for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Hymenolepis diminuta

Hymenolepis diminuta, or rat tapeworm, is a parasitic tapeworm that primarily infects rodents but can occasionally infect humans through ingestion of infected insects.

Morphology

Adult Worm:

Large (20-60 cm) and slender, with a scolex that lacks hooks and has four suckers for attachment. Composed of many proglottids with both male and female organs.

Egg:

 
  • Eggs of H. diminuta are slightly oval, larger than those of H. nana, measuring around 60-80 µm in diameter.
  • They have a thick outer shell, a yellowish color, and lack polar filaments (distinguishing them from H. nana eggs).
  • Inside, there is an oncosphere (embryo) with six hooks that will aid in initial attachment upon ingestion by the insect host.

Life Cycle
  • Intermediate Host (Insects): Eggs ingested by insects (e.g., beetles, fleas) develop into cysticercoid larvae.
  • Definitive Host (Rodent/Human): Infection occurs when an insect with cysticercoid larvae is ingested. The larvae develop into adults in the host’s small intestine.
  • Human Accidental Host: Humans are infected through accidental ingestion of infected insects; direct human-to-human transmission is rare.

Clinical Features

Asymptomatic: Many human infections are asymptomatic, especially when there is a low parasite load.

 

Symptoms (in heavy infections): Abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and occasional weight loss.

Investigations
  • Stool Microscopy: Key diagnostic tool that reveals characteristic eggs that lack polar filaments.
  • Serology/PCR: Molecular confirmation in research or doubtful cases.

Management

Anthelmintics: Praziquantel (preferred) - single dose.

questions.text: An egg was extracted and observed under the microscope. Which of the following species does it belong to?
questions.explanation:
Hymenolepis nana (Dwarf Tapeworm)

Hymenolepis nana, or dwarf tapeworm, is a parasitic cestode primarily infecting humans and rodents, commonly causing infection in children.

It can complete its life cycle in a single host without requiring an intermediate host.

Morphology
  • Adult Worm: Measures 15–40 mm in length; features a scolex with four suckers and a retractable rostellum with hooks for attachment to the intestinal wall.
  • Proglottids: Segmented body, with each segment containing both male and female reproductive organs.

Life Cycle
  • Infective Stage: Eggs are excreted in feces and can survive in the environment.
  • Autoinfection: Ingested eggs hatch in the intestine, allowing direct development into adults, leading to reinfection.
  • Ingestion: Humans acquire infection by consuming contaminated food or water. Rodents can also act as hosts.
  • Larval Development: Oncospheres hatch in the intestine, penetrate intestinal villi, and develop into cysticercoids.
  • Maturation: Cysticercoids mature into adults in about 20–30 days, attaching to the intestinal wall and producing eggs.

Clinical features
  • Asymptomatic in many cases.
  • Symptomatic individuals may experience:
    • Abdominal pain and cramps
    • Diarrhea or loose stools
    • Loss of appetite and weight loss
    • Irritability (especially in children)
    • Nausea and vomiting (less common)

Investigations
  • Stool Examination: Microscopic detection of eggs using methods like Kato-Katz or concentration techniques.
  • PCR: Used for specific identification of H. nana DNA in stool samples.

Management

Antiparasitic Medication:

  • Praziquantel: First-line treatment, typically a single oral dose of 25 mg/kg.
  • Alternative: Nitazoxanide.

Features

Taenia Species

Diphyllobothrium latum

Hymenolepis nana

Hymenolepis diminuta

Egg Appearance

Brownish/yellow-brown, thick-shelled

Yellow-brown, operculated


 

Colourless to yellow-brown, thin-shelled



 

Similar to H. nana, slightly larger



 

Size (Diameter)

30-43 µm

50-76 µm

30-45 µm

40-70 µm

Shape

Spherical/ovoid

Ellipsoidal

Oval to Spherical

Oval to Spherical

Shell Characteristics

Striated (thick)

Operculum at one end, thin shell

Smooth, no striations

Smooth, no striations

Bile Staining

Negative

Positive

Negative

Negative

Other Features

Contains hooks in the larval stage (cysticercus); no hooks in T. saginata

Terminal knob at the opposite end

Contains polar filaments

Polar filaments, typically absent

Embryo Development

Cysticercus larva can develop within the host

Proglottids shed in water, release eggs

Can develop into an adult in a single host.

Requires an intermediate host (usually rodents)

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly differentiates between Hymenolepis nana and Hymenolepis diminuta?

options.label: A
options.text: H. nana has hooks on its rostellum; H. diminuta does not

options.label: B
options.text: H. nana requires two intermediate hosts; H. diminuta requires one

options.label: C
options.text: H. diminuta exhibits autoinfection; H. nana does not

options.label: D
options.text: H. nana is the rat tapeworm; H. diminuta is the dwarf tapeworm

questions.correct_answer: A. H. nana has hooks on its rostellum; H. diminuta does not
questions.explanation:
Hymenolepis nana and Hymenolepis diminuta

Feature

Hymenolepis nana (H. nana)

Hymenolepis diminuta (H. diminuta)

Common Name (Option D)

Dwarf tapeworm

Rat tapeworm

Definitive Hosts

Humans, rodents

Primarily rodents, occasionally humans

Intermediate Host

(Option B)

Optional, can complete life cycle in a single host

Required, typically insects (e.g., beetles, fleas)

Egg

Oval and 37 to 47 µm in diameter, and has a double-layered shell that encloses filaments arising from bipolar thickenings

Rounder and 60 to 85 µm in diameter and have no polar filaments.

Adult Size

15-40 mm long

20-60 cm long

Scolex (Option A)

Four suckers, retractable rostellum with hooks

Four suckers, no hooks

Infective Stage

Embryonated eggs (directly infective)

Cysticercoid larva in the intermediate host

Mode of Transmission

(Option C)

Fecal-oral, autoinfection possible

Ingestion of infected intermediate host

Life Cycle

Simple, can complete cycle within one host

Complex, requires two hosts

Diagnostic Method

Identification of eggs in stool samples

Identification of eggs in stool samples

Treatment

Praziquantel or niclosamide

Praziquantel

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with liver imaging that reveals a cystic mass with an invasive, infiltrative growth pattern spreading into surrounding tissues. Serology confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following species is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Echinococcus multilocularis (Alveolar Echinococcosis)

Echinococcus granulosus (Cystic Echinococcosis)

(Option A)

Cyst Structure

Multi-chambered, invasive, tumor-like growth

Single, large fluid-filled cyst with thick laminated wall

Growth Pattern

Infiltrative, resembles malignancy, spreads to nearby tissues

Expansive, non-invasive, contained within a single cyst

Common Sites

Primarily liver

Can metastasise (e.g., lungs, brain)

Mostly liver, sometimes lungs

Calcification

Common, granular appearance on imaging

Less common, cyst typically has a "water lily" sign

Treatment

Complex; surgery and long-term albendazole, poor prognosis

Surgery is often effective, sometimes with albendazole

questions.text: A 39-year-old male presents with abdominal pain and a palpable abdominal mass. Ultrasound imaging shows findings depicted in the accompanying image. Based on the WHO classification of hydatid cysts, to which stage does this cyst correspond?
questions.explanation:
WHO Classification

Cyst Type

Ultrasound Findings

CL

Unilocular Cyst

Cystic lesion and no visible cyst wall

CE1 (Option A)

Simple Active Cyst

Double-line sign; well-defined anechoic cyst

CE2 (Option B)

Multivesicular Cyst

Honeycomb appearance: Visible cyst wall and internal septations

CE3

Transitional Cyst

Have detached laminar membranes or may be partially collapsed, and floating within the cyst cavity (Water-lily sign)

CE4 (Option D)

Inactive Cyst

Non-homogenous mass

CE5

Inactive Cyst

Cyst with a thick calcified wall

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with abdominal pain, nausea, and occasional fever. On examination, a palpable mass is detected in the right upper quadrant. The patient mentions a recent trip to a region known for livestock farming. An ultrasound reveals a cystic structure with characteristic internal septations. Based on these findings, which layer of the cyst is primarily involved in protecting the parasite from the host's immune system?
questions.explanation:
Layer

Name

Origin

Description

Main Function

Outer Layer

Pericyst

Host-derived
  • Thick fibrous layer created by the host's inflammatory response around the cyst.
  • Eventually it develops into a dense fibrous capsule which may even calcify.

Provides structural support and isolates the cyst from surrounding tissues.

Middle Layer

Ectocyst (Laminated Membrane)

Parasite-derived
  • Acellular, chitinous, laminated hyaline layer secreted by the parasite.
  • Has the appearance of the white of a hard-boiled egg.

Acts as a barrier against host immune cells and protects the inner germinal layer.

Inner Layer

Endocyst (Germinal Layer)

Parasite-derived
  • Thin cellular layer lining the cyst interior.
  • Consists of a number of nuclei embedded in a protoplasmic mass.
  • Vital layer of the cyst.
  • Site of asexual reproduction giving rise to brood capsules with scolices.
  • Also secrete hydatid fluid, which fills the cyst.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male is diagnosed with hydatid cysts. Which of the following serves as the accidental intermediate host in this infection?
questions.explanation:
Other name

Dog tapeworm

Definitive Host

Dog (optimal host), wolf, jackal and fox (Option A & B)

Intermediate Host

Sheep and cattle (Option C)

Accidental Intermediate Host

Man (Harbors larval stage, not adult form) (Option D)

Infective Form

Embryonated egg

Mode of Infection

Ingestion of the eggs due to:

  • Intimate handling of infected dogs
  • Eating raw vegetables or other food items contaminated with dog feces

Eggs

  • Ovoid in shape and brown in color
  • Contains an embryo with three pairs of hooklets

Larva

Represent the structure of the scolex of the adult worm and remains invaginated within a vesicular body.

Adult Worm
  • Consists of scolex, a short neck and strobila
  • Scolex is pyriform, with four suckers and prominent rostellum bearing two circular rows of hooklets.

questions.text: A 34-year-old patient presents with gastrointestinal discomfort and reports passing segments in stool. Stool microscopy shows Taenia eggs, but further tests are needed for species identification. Which test best differentiates Taenia saginata from Taenia solium, and what is the drug of choice?

options.label: A
options.text: MRI to detect non-calcified cysts; Praziquantel

options.label: C
options.text: Microscopy of gravid proglottids to count lateral uterine branches; Praziquantel

options.label: D
options.text: Stool concentration using the formol-ether sedimentation method; Albendazole

questions.correct_answer: C. Microscopy of gravid proglottids to count lateral uterine branches; Praziquantel

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with a history of multiple painless subcutaneous nodules (shown below), seizures, and recent neurological symptoms. The patient has a history of consuming undercooked pork. Microscopy of a biopsy from one of the subcutaneous nodules reveals larval forms with a scolex. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Cysticercosis

Infection
  • direct consumption of T. solium eggs via contaminated food
  • Caused by the larval stage (cysticercus cellulosae) of Taenia solium.

Pathology

  • Can affect any organ or tissue, with the most common sites being subcutaneous tissues and muscles.
  • Other affected areas include
    • Eyes and the brain
    • Less often, heart, liver, lungs, abdominal cavity and spinal cord.
  • Cysticercus is surrounded by a fibrous capsule except in the eye and brain ventricles.
  • The larvae trigger a cellular reaction, initially involving neutrophils, eosinophils, lymphocytes, plasma cells, and occasionally giant cells.
  • This reaction leads to fibrosis, death of the larva, and eventual calcification.

Clinical Features

Depends on the affected site:

  • Subcutaneous cysticercosis: Mostly presents as asymptomatic nodules.
  • Muscular cysticercosis: May cause acute myositis.
  • Neurocysticercosis (cysticercosis of the brain):
    • Most common and severe form.
    • Second most common cause of intracranial space-occupying lesions (ICSOL) in India, after tuberculosis.
    • Symptoms include:
      • Adult-onset epilepsy: M/c
      • Increased intracranial pressure
      • Hydrocephalus
      • Psychiatric disturbances
      • Meningoencephalitis
      • Transient paresis
      • Behavioural disorders
      • Aphasia
      • Visual disturbances
 
  • Ocular cysticercosis:
    • Cysts are found in the vitreous humour, subretinal space, and conjunctiva.
    • Symptoms may include blurred vision or vision loss, iritis, uveitis, and palpebral conjunctivitis.

Intestinal taeniasis

Infection

Via consumption of undercooked infected meat of beef (T. saginata) or pork(T. solium)

Clinical features

Adult worms, despite their large size, cause little discomfort to the patient.

  • When symptoms do occur, they may include:
    • Vague abdominal discomfort
    • Indigestion
    • Nausea
    • Diarrhea
    • Weight loss
  • Rarely, complications such as acute intestinal obstruction, acute appendicitis, and pancreatitis.

questions.text: Identify the correct feature of the given group of organisms.

options.label: A
options.text: They have a complete alimentary canal

questions.explanation:
Cestodes

Trematodes

Nematodes

These are long and segmented worms.

These are leaf-like and unsegmented.

These are elongated unsegmented worms.

They are dorsoventrally flattened and have no body cavity. (Option D)

These are also flatworms without a body cavity.

These are cylindrical worms and have a body cavity with well-differentiated organs.

They have no alimentary canal. (Option A)

They have an incomplete alimentary canal without an anus.

They have a complete alimentary canal.
  • They have suckers for attaching to the host.
  • Some have hooks as well. (Option B)
  • Suckers are present.
  • Hooks are absent.

Hooks and suckers are absent.

These are hermaphrodites (monoecious) (Option C)

Hermaphrodites except Schistosoma.

The sexes are separate (diecious)

Examples:

  • Diphyllobothrium
  • Taenia saginata
  • Taenia solium
  • Echinococcus granulosus
  • Hymenolepis nana
  • Dipylidium caninum

Examples:

  • Intestinal flukes:
    • Fasciolopsis buski
  • Blood flukes:
    • Schistosoma mansoni

Examples:

  • Small intestinal nematodes:
    • Ascaris
    • Hookworm
    • Strongyloides
  • Large intestinal:
    • Trichuris
    • Enterobius

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient presents with gastrointestinal symptoms, including abdominal pain and diarrhea. A stool examination reveals the presence of tapeworm segments. Which of the following statements correctly differentiates between Taenia saginata and Taenia solium?

options.label: A
options.text: T. saginata has a small globular scolex, while T. solium has a large quadrate scolex.

options.label: B
options.text: T. saginata has fewer than 1000 proglottids, whereas T. solium has more than 1000

options.label: C
options.text: T. saginata possesses rostellum and hooks, while T. solium lacks rostellum and hooks

options.label: D
options.text: T. saginata has thin, dichotomous uterine branches, while T. solium has thick, dendritic uterine branches

questions.correct_answer: D. T. saginata has thin, dichotomous uterine branches, while T. solium has thick, dendritic uterine branches
questions.explanation:
Feature

Taenia saginata No

Taenia solium

Image

Length

5-10 meters

2-3 meters

Scolex (Option A & C)
  • Large quadrate
  • Rostellum and hooks are absent
  • Suckers may be pigmented
  • Small and globular
  • Rostellum and hooks are present
  • Suckers not pigmented

Neck

Long

Short

Proglottids (Option B)

1000-2000

Below 1000

Measurement (gravid segment)

20 mm X 5 mm

12 mm X 6 mm

Expulsion

Expelled singly

Expelled passively in chains of 5 or 6

Uterus (Option D)

Lateral branches 15-30 on each side; thin and dichotomous

Lateral branches 5-10 on each side; thick and dendritic

Vagina

Present

Absent

Accessory lobe of ovary

Absent

Present

Testes

300-400 follicles

15-200 follicles

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents with complaints of tingling in her hands and feet, along with weakness and fatigue. She has a history of consuming undercooked fish. Laboratory tests reveal macrocytic anemia and elevated mean corpuscular volume (MCV). A stool examination shows operculated eggs. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Diphyllobothrium latum


 

Clinical Features
  • Most infections are asymptomatic; only a few individuals develop symptoms.
  • Minor Symptoms: These may include abdominal discomfort, diarrhoea, nausea, vomiting, weakness, and weight loss.
  • Rarely, patients may experience acute abdominal pain due to intestinal obstruction, cholangitis, or cholecystitis.
  • Vitamin B12 Deficiency: The adult worm interferes with the vitamin B12-intrinsic factor complex, leading to decreased absorption in the ileum, resulting in megaloblastic anemia (bothriocephalus anemia) and neurological sequelae (e.g., paresthesia). (Option B)

Laboratory Diagnosis

Stool Examination: Identifies characteristic operculated eggs; they are:

  • Bile-stained,
  • Operculated with a knob.
  • Do not float in the saturated salt solution.
  • Molecular Testing: PCR and sequencing allow for precise species identification.
  • Blood Tests: Eosinophilia and megaloblastic anaemia indicators include:
  • Increased MCV & MCH
  • Normal MCHC
  • Macrocytes

Treatment
  • Drug of Choice: Praziquantel (5–10 mg/kg once).
  • Alternative Option: Niclosamide.
  • Parenteral vitamin B12 should be administered if B12 deficiency is evident.

questions.text: A medical student is studying various parasitic infections and learns that certain parasites are characterized by operculate eggs. Which of the following parasites is not associated with operculate eggs?
questions.explanation:
Egg of Diphyllobothrium latum
  • A single D. latum worm can lay approximately one million eggs daily.
  • Egg is broadly ovoid, about 65 µm by 45 µm, with a thick, light brown shell.
  • It has an operculum at one end and often a small knob at the other.
  • Freshly passed eggs contain an immature embryo surrounded by yolk granules, with the embryo referred to as an oncosphere, which has six hooklets.
  • Eggs are resistant to chemicals but are vulnerable to drying.
  • Eggs do not float in saturated salt solution and exhibit bile staining.
  • These eggs are not infectious to humans.

Parasites with operculate eggs
  • Fasciola hepatica (Option A)
  • Fasciola gigantica
  • Fasciolopsis buski
  • Clonorchis sinensis (Option C)
  • Paragonimus westermani
  • Gastrodiscoides hominis
  • Opisthorchis felineus
  • Opisthorchis viverrini
  • Heterophyes heterophyes

(All Trematodes except schistosoma)

  • Diphyllobothrium latum (Option B)
  • Spirometra

questions.text: A 28-year-old female with a history of consuming locally caught fish presents with complaints of weakness and mild abdominal pain. Her stool sample reveals eggs, as shown in the figure. Which form of the parasite would have been present in the fish she consumed?
questions.explanation:
Diphyllobothrium latum

Also known as Fish tapeworm/Broad tapeworm, it is the largest and longest cestode found infecting the human intestine.

Morphology

  • Adult Worm: Can grow >15 meters in length with more than 3,000 segments (proglottids); has a scolex (head) with two grooves (bothria). No suckers and hooklets.
  • Egg: Operculated structure.
  • Larvae: Develops in three stages:
  • Coracidium (L1)
  • Procercoid (L2)
  • Plerocercoid (L3)

Life Cycle
  • Requires 3 hosts:
    • Definitive Host: Humans, cats and dogs, where the adult worm resides in the intestine.
    • 1st Intermediate Host: Cyclops (small crustacean).
    • 2nd Intermediate Host: Fish.
  • Human Infection: Occurs by consuming undercooked fish containing the L3 (plerocercoid) larva.
 

Transmission and Development:

  • In Cyclops: Eggs in water hatch to L1 (coracidium) larva (Option A), which infects Cyclops and matures to L2 (procercoid) larva (Option B).
  • In Fish: L2 larva further matures to L3 (plerocercoid) larva (Option C), the infective form for humans.
  • In Humans: The L3 larva matures into an adult (Option D) in the small intestine and produces eggs that are excreted in feces (diagnostic form).

questions.text: A 38-year-old female from a rural farming community presents with upper abdominal pain, weight loss, and fatigue. Physical examination reveals hepatomegaly, and ultrasound reveals a well-defined cystic lesion in the liver with internal septations. What is the most likely pathogen causing this condition?
questions.explanation:
Intestinal cestodes

Somatic cestodes

These are commonly found infesting the intestines.

These are found in other parts of the body, like muscles, the brain, etc.

Taenia saginata: The beef tapeworm

  • Man is the definitive host.

Echinococcus: The dog tapeworm

  • Larva causes hydatid disease.
  • Man is an accidental intermediate host.

Taenia solium: The pork tapeworm

  • Man is the definitive host.

Taenia solium (Option A)

  • Larva causes cysticercus cellulosae.
  • Man is the definitive host.

Hymenolopis nana: The dwarf tapeworm (Option B)

  • It is the smallest intestinal cestode.
  • Man is the definitive host.
  • No intermediate host.

Taenia multiceps

  • Humans are accidental intermediate hosts.

Diphyllobothrium latum: The fish tapeworm

  • Man is a definitive host.

Spirometra (Option D)

  • Larva causes sparganosis.
  • Man is an accidental intermediate host.

Intestinal cestodes

Somatic cestodes

  • Taenia saginata
  • Taenia solium
  • Hymenolopis nana
  • Diphyllobothrium latum
  • Echinococcus
  • Taenia solium
  • Taenia multiceps
  • Spirometra

questions.text: Match the following cestodes with the right features. Organism Features i) Taenia solium a. 4 suckers, no hooks ii) Taenia saginata b. 4 suckers, single row of 20-30 hooks iii) Hymenolopis nana c. 2 suctorial grooves or bothria, no suckers, no hooks iv) Diphyllobothrium latum d. 4 suckers, 2 rows of hooks
questions.explanation:
Morphology of cestodes

  • Cestodes are dorsoventrally flat and segmented intestinal worms that may vary in size from a few millimetres to several meters.
  • They are made of three parts:
    • Head or scolex
    • Neck
    • Trunk

Distinguishing features of the different cestodes

Cestode

Taenia solium

Taenia saginata

Hymenolepis nana

Hymenolepis diminuta

Diphyllobothrium latum

Echinococcus granulosis

 

Head features

4 suckers

2 rows of hooks

4 suckers

No hooks

4 suckers

Single row of 20-30 hooks

4 suckers

No hooks

2 suctorial grooves or bothria

No suckers

No hooks

4 suckers

2 rows of hooks



 

Images

Taenia solium

T. saginata

  

Hymenolepis nana

  

Hymenolepis diminuta

  

Diphyllobothrium latum

  

Echinococcus granulosis

questions.text: A microbiologist is examining the stool sample of a patient suspected to have a helminth infestation. Which of the following methods would be the best to assess bile staining property of helminth eggs?
questions.explanation:
Stool sample processing

Microscopic examination of stool samples

This is done by two methods:

  • Direct wet mount examination
  • Permanent staining methods

Direct wet mount

 

Preparation:

  • Drops of saline and Lugol’s iodine are used on the left and right sides of the slide.
  • Mix ~2 mg of feces to form a smooth suspension.
  • Place a coverslip on the mount for examination under a microscope.

Observation:

  • Trophozoites
  • Normal constituents of stool like plant fibers and starch cells can be seen
  • Cellular Elements:
    • Pus cells (in inflammatory diarrhea)
    • Red blood cells (in dysentery)
  • Charcot-Leyden Crystals


 

 

Types of wet mounts:

Saline mount:

  • Uses: Detects trophozoites, cysts, helminth eggs, and larvae.
  • Advantages:
    • Demonstrates motility of trophozoites and larvae.
    • Bile staining property can be assessed (bile-stained eggs appear golden brown).

Iodine mount:

  • Advantages: Better visualization of nuclear details in cysts, larvae, and eggs.
  • Disadvantages:
    • Iodine immobilizes and kills parasites, hindering motility observation. (Option A)
    • Bile staining property cannot be assessed.

Permanent stained smears
  • This method stains the internal structures.
  • Purpose: For accurate detection of protozoan cysts and trophozoites.
  • Common Stains:
    • Iron-hematoxylin stain.
    • Trichrome stain.
    • Modified acid-fast stain for coccidian parasites (e.g., Cryptosporidium).

questions.text: Which of the following parasites does not have humans as its definitive host?
questions.explanation:
Hosts

A host is an organism that supports a parasite, providing it with nourishment and shelter, and is typically larger than the parasite.

Definitive host
  • This is the host where the adult stage of the parasite resides and undergoes sexual reproduction.
  • Examples:
    • Mosquito: Acts as the definitive host for the malaria parasite.
    • Humans: Often serve as definitive hosts for various parasites like
      • Taenia solium (pork tapeworm)(Option D)
      • Taenia saginata (beef tapeworm)
      • Enterobius vermicularis (pinworm)(Option A)
      • Ascaris lumbricoides (roundworm)
      • Ancylostoma duodenale (hookworm)(Option B)
      • Necator americanus (hookworm)
      • Trichuris trichiura (whipworm)
      • Schistosoma species (blood flukes)
      • Strongyloides stercoralis (threadworm)

Intermediate host
  • This host is where the larval stage of the parasite lives or where asexual reproduction occurs.
  • Some parasites may require two different intermediate hosts to complete their life cycle, referred to as the first and second intermediate hosts.
  • Example: Humans are intermediate hosts in:
    • Babesia spp.
    • Echinococcus granulosus (Option C)
    • Echinococcus multiocularis
    • Toxoplasma gondii
    • Plasmodium spp.

Paratenic host
  • This type of host allows the larval stage of the parasite to remain viable without further development.
  • It acts as a carrier that can transmit the infection to another host.
  • Example: Fish can serve as a paratenic host for the plerocercoid larva of Diphyllobothrium.

Reservoir host
  • In endemic areas, a reservoir host continually maintains the presence of a parasite, serving as a significant source of infection for other susceptible hosts.
  • Example: Dogs are reservoir hosts for hydatid disease.

Accidental host
  • This host is not typically part of the parasite's life cycle.
  • Example: Humans can be accidental hosts for cystic echinococcosis.
